s0102: He was normally not on good terms with Cao Can, and when He became ill, Emperor Hui personally visited to see the prime minister's illness, and asked: 'If after you reach a hundred years, who can replace you?'
s0103: He replied: 'No one knows a minister better than his ruler.'
s0104: Emperor Hui said: 'What about Cao Can?'
s0105: He bowed his head to the ground and said: 'Your majesty has obtained him!
s0108: He placed his fields and houses in poor locations, and for his household did not repair walls and roofs.
s0109: He said: 'If later generations are worthy, they will emulate my frugality;
s0110: if not worthy, do not let powerful families seize it.'
s0112: In Emperor Hui year 2, Prime Minister He died, given the posthumous title Marquis of Wen.
s0113: Later descendants lost the marquisate through crime for four generations, it was extinguished, but the Son of Heaven always sought He's descendants again, enfeoffed them to continue the Wan marquisateâ€”no other meritorious official could compare.
s0114: The Grand Historian says: Chancellor Xiao He during Qin times was a clerk with writing brush, undistinguished without extraordinary conduct.
s0115: When Han arose, relying on the remaining light of sun and moon, He carefully guarded the keys and pipes, took advantage of the people's hatred of [Qin] law, followed the current and began anew with them.
s0116: Huaiyin, Ying Bu and others all perished through execution, while He's merit shines brilliantly.
s0117: His position crowned the ministers, his reputation extends to later generations, contending in glory with Hong Yao, San Yisheng and others.
